DOC.HEAD: Influenza Epidemic Kills 102 More
DOC.TEXT: Britain's worst flu epidemic in 15 years claimed at least 102 more lives this month, raising the death toll to 126, according to government figures released Tuesday. Doctors estimate that more than 1 million Britons are suffering from the English flu, a variant of Hong Kong flu that swept Britain in the winter of 1974-75. The Royal Society of General Practitioners said infection levels have reached epidemic levels. Most of the latest deaths, all recorded in the first week of December, were of people over age 65, according to the Office of Population Censuses and Surveys that monitors flu deaths year-round. In Geneva, the World Health Organization said influenza was also spreading through Continental Europe. Karin Esteves, of the WHO's Division of Communicable Diseases, said the outbreak in Britain was not as serious as in the earlier epidemic. ``But we don't think it has already peaked,'' she told The Associated Press in the telephone interview. She said that in France, the disease is spreading rapidly from Paris and into the South. Reports from Belgium, Switzerland and the Soviet Union also suggest the flu outbreak is growing worse in those places. She added that occasional vaccine shortages may occur because of the high demand. Symptoms of the disease include fatigue, aching muscles, headaches, coughing and prolonged fever lasting four or five days.
